The War Cabinet were informed of the course of the debate that day in the House of Commons on the coal situation.The Prim,e Minister said that he would intervene in the debate on the following day. Discussion ensued on the points raised in debate, and as to the line which the Prime Minister should take.It was agreed that this should consist, broadly, of a reaffirmationand re-emphasis of the line of policy set out in W.P. (43) 451 and approved by the War Cabinet on the previous day, against the background of the position of a Coalition Government, pledged tocarry out whatever measures might be necessary for the effectiveprosecution of the war.The War Cabinet was, however, informed that there was someapprehension that the present system of control over the operationof the mines might be brought to an end suddenly at the end of thewar (as had happened after the last war), notwithstanding theundertaking given in paragraph 13 of Cmd. 6364 that "theorganisation now to be established will continue pending a finaldecision by Parliament on the future of the Industry."The War Cabinet agreed that this undertaking should be amended by an addition to the effect that the present system ofcontrol would, in any event, be continued for at least a year afterthe end of the war; and the Prime Minister should include this inhis speech.Coal.(previous reference:W.M. (43) 138thConclusions,Minute 5.)Wage-Earners' 2. The Chancellor of the Exchequer informed the WarIncome Tax Cabinet that, in his statement on the Second Reading of the Bill onBiJ1- Thursday, the 14th October, he proposed to indicate that he wouldgive sympathetic consideration to the possibility of includingwithin the scope of the Wage Earners' Income Tax Bill salariedworkers in the lower income groups.He thought it right to report this to the War Cabinet as being a modification of the proposal previously approved.The War Cabinet-Took note, with approval, of this statement.Offices of the War Cabinet, S.W. 1,13th October, 1943.
